docs.title: Security Model
docs.text: Understanding Vaultix's security guarantees and limitations.

docs.title: What Vaultix Protects Against ✓
docs.text:
• Unauthorized file access: Files are encrypted at rest with AES-256-GCM
  • Casual snooping: Encrypted data is unreadable without the password
  • Filename leakage: Original filenames are encrypted in metadata
  • Data tampering: GCM provides authentication, detecting modifications

docs.title: What Vaultix Does NOT Protect Against ✗
docs.text:
• Weak passwords: A guessable password defeats all encryption
  • Keyloggers/malware: If your system is compromised, passwords can be captured
  • Memory attacks: Decrypted data exists in memory during operations
  • Physical access: Someone with your password and physical access can decrypt
  • Legal compulsion: Courts can order you to provide passwords
  • Side-channel attacks: Advanced attacks on the cryptographic implementation

docs.title: Key Derivation: Argon2id
docs.text:
Algorithm: Argon2id (winner of Password Hashing Competition)

Parameters:

  • Memory: 64 MB
  • Iterations: 1
  • Parallelism: 4 threads
  • Output: 32 bytes (256 bits)

Why Argon2id?

  • Resistant to GPU/ASIC attacks
  • Protects against side-channel attacks
  • Recommended by OWASP
  • Balanced between Argon2i (side-channel resistant) and Argon2d (GPU resistant)

docs.title: Encryption: AES-256-GCM
docs.text:
Algorithm: Advanced Encryption Standard with Galois/Counter Mode

Key size: 256 bits Nonce size: 96 bits (12 bytes) Authentication tag: 128 bits (16 bytes)

Why AES-256-GCM?

  • Industry standard, extensively analyzed
  • Provides both confidentiality and authenticity
  • Authenticated encryption prevents tampering
  • Hardware acceleration available on modern CPUs
  • NIST approved

docs.title: Random Number Generation
docs.text:
Source: Go's crypto/rand package

Uses OS-provided cryptographically secure random number generators:

  • Linux: /dev/urandom
  • macOS: SecRandomCopyBytes
  • Windows: CryptGenRandom

docs.title: Password Flow
docs.text:
1. Input: Password entered via terminal (no echo)
  2. Derivation: Argon2id generates 256-bit key
  3. Usage: Key encrypts/decrypts data
  4. Cleanup: Key zeroed in memory after use

docs.title: No Password Storage
docs.text:
Vaultix never stores:

  • ✗ Your password
  • ✗ Password hashes
  • ✗ Password hints
  • ✗ Recovery keys

Password correctness is verified by attempting to decrypt the metadata. Incorrect password = decryption failure.

docs.title: Password Requirements
docs.text:
Vaultix enforces:

  • Minimum length: 1 character (but please use more!)
  • Maximum length: No limit

Recommended:

  • At least 16 characters
  • Mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols
  • Use a password manager
  • Don't reuse passwords
  • Consider a passphrase (e.g., "correct horse battery staple")

docs.title: Encryption Process
docs.text:
Plaintext File
    ↓
Read into memory
    ↓
Generate random nonce
    ↓
AES-256-GCM encryption with derived key
    ↓
Encrypted data + authentication tag
    ↓
Write to .vaultix/objects/
    ↓
Secure delete original file

docs.title: Decryption Process
docs.text:
Encrypted object
    ↓
Read from .vaultix/objects/
    ↓
Extract nonce from ciphertext
    ↓
AES-256-GCM decryption with derived key
    ↓
Verify authentication tag
    ↓
Plaintext data
    ↓
Write to output file

docs.title: What's in Metadata
docs.text:
• Original filenames
  • File sizes
  • Modification timestamps
  • Object IDs (encrypted file references)

docs.title: Metadata Protection
docs.text:
• Encrypted: Metadata is encrypted with AES-256-GCM
  • Authenticated: Tampering is detected
  • Single file: All metadata in one encrypted blob

Why encrypt metadata?

Filenames can reveal sensitive information:

  • tax_return_2024.pdf → Financial data
  • medical_records.txt → Health information
  • job_applications.docx → Employment status

docs.title: Secure Deletion
docs.text:
When files are deleted (after encryption or with drop/remove):

  1. Overwrite: File contents overwritten with random data
  2. Delete: File unlinked from filesystem

Limitations:

  • SSDs may not physically overwrite due to wear leveling
  • Copy-on-write filesystems (Btrfs, ZFS) may keep copies
  • Filesystem journaling may preserve data
  • Swap/hibernation files may contain plaintext

Recommendation: Use full-disk encryption (LUKS, FileVault, BitLocker) alongside Vaultix.

docs.title: Scenario 1: Stolen Laptop
docs.text:
Attack: Thief gets your laptop with encrypted vault

Protection:

  • ✓ Files are encrypted with AES-256
  • ✓ Decryption requires password
  • ✓ Brute-force is slow (Argon2id)

Outcome: Data is safe if password is strong

docs.title: Scenario 2: Cloud Backup
docs.text:
Attack: Cloud provider compromised, vault backup leaked

Protection:

  • ✓ Vault is fully encrypted
  • ✓ Metadata is encrypted
  • ✓ Object names don't reveal content

Outcome: Data is safe (same as stolen laptop)

docs.title: Scenario 3: Malware on System
docs.text:
Attack: Keylogger captures password while you use vault

Protection:

  • ✗ Password is captured as you type
  • ✗ Decrypted files can be read from memory
  • ✗ Extracted files can be stolen

Outcome: Vaultix cannot protect against compromised systems

Mitigation: Keep your system clean, use antivirus, practice safe computing

docs.title: Scenario 4: Physical Access While Unlocked
docs.text:
Attack: Someone accesses your computer while you're away

Protection:

  • ✗ Files may be extracted
  • ✗ Password may be in command history
  • ✗ Decrypted files may be on disk

Outcome: Lock your computer when away

Mitigation: Use screen lock, log out, close terminal after vault operations

docs.title: Scenario 5: Weak Password
docs.text:
Attack: Attacker brute-forces your password

Protection:

  • ⚠️ Argon2id slows down attacks
  • ✗ Weak passwords are still crackable

Outcome: Security depends on password strength

Mitigation: Use strong, unique passwords (16+ characters)

docs.title: DO ✓
docs.text:
• Use strong, unique passwords
  • Store vaults on encrypted drives
  • Lock your computer when away
  • Keep your OS and software updated
  • Use a password manager
  • Make encrypted backups
  • Test your backups regularly

docs.title: DON'T ✗
docs.text:
• Reuse passwords
  • Store passwords in plaintext
  • Leave decrypted files lying around
  • Use vaultix over unencrypted connections
  • Trust public computers
  • Forget to lock your screen

docs.title: Auditing
docs.text:
Vaultix has not undergone formal security auditing. The code is open source for community review, but no independent security firm has assessed it.

Use at your own risk.

docs.title: Reporting Security Issues
docs.text:
If you discover a security vulnerability:

  1. DO NOT open a public issue
  2. Email security concerns privately
  3. Include details and reproduction steps
  4. Allow time for fix before disclosure

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
Vaultix provides strong cryptographic protection for files at rest. However, it's not a silver bullet:

  • 🔐 Strong encryption protects data from unauthorized access
  • 🔑 Security depends on password strength
  • 💻 Cannot protect against compromised systems
  • 🎯 Best used alongside other security measures

Think of Vaultix as one layer in your security strategy, not the only layer.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Solutions to common problems with vaultix.

docs.title: "Command not found: vaultix"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix init
bash: vaultix: command not found

Cause: Binary not in PATH or not installed.

Solutions:

1. Check if binary exists:

# Find vaultix binary
which vaultix
ls -l ~/bin/vaultix

2. Add to PATH:

# Temporary (current session)
export PATH="$PATH:$HOME/bin"

# Permanent (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
echo 'export PATH="$PATH:$HOME/bin"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

3. Reinstall:

# Download and install
curl -LO https://github.com/Zayan-Mohamed/vaultix/releases/latest/download/vaultix-linux-amd64
chmod +x vaultix-linux-amd64
mv vaultix-linux-amd64 ~/bin/vaultix

docs.title: "Permission denied" when running vaultix
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ ./vaultix
bash: ./vaultix: Permission denied

Cause: Binary not executable.

Solution:

chmod +x vaultix
./vaultix --version

docs.title: Build fails with "Go version too old"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

go: go.mod requires go >= 1.21

Cause: Go version too old.

Solution:

# Check Go version
go version

# Update Go
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo snap install go --classic

# macOS
brew install go

# Windows
# Download from https://golang.org/dl/

docs.title: "Vault not found"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix list
Error: vault not found

Cause: No .vaultix directory in current location.

Solutions:

1. Check if vault exists:

ls -la .vaultix

2. Initialize vault:

vaultix init

3. Navigate to correct directory:

cd /path/to/vault
vaultix list

docs.title: "Password incorrect" (but you're sure it's right)
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix list
Enter password: ****
Error: password incorrect

Possible causes:

1. Typing error:

  • Extra spaces
  • Caps Lock enabled
  • Wrong keyboard layout
  • Auto-correct changed password

Solution:

# Type password in text editor to verify
echo "password123" > /tmp/pass.txt
cat /tmp/pass.txt | vaultix list
rm /tmp/pass.txt  # Clean up

2. Different password used during init:

Solution:

  • Try to remember which password you used
  • Restore from backup if available
  • No recovery possible if password forgotten

3. Vault corrupted:

Solution:

  • Restore from backup
  • See "Vault Corrupted" section below

docs.title: "Vault already exists"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix init
Error: vault already exists

Cause: .vaultix directory already present.

Solutions:

1. List existing vault:

vaultix list

2. Remove vault (DESTRUCTIVE):

# WARNING: This deletes all encrypted files!
rm -rf .vaultix
vaultix init

3. Use different directory:

mkdir new_vault
cd new_vault
vaultix init

docs.title: "File not found in vault"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix extract document.pdf
Error: file not found in vault

Causes & Solutions:

1. Typo in filename:

# List all files
vaultix list

# Use fuzzy match
vaultix extract doc  # Will match "document.pdf"

2. File never added:

# Add file first
vaultix add document.pdf
vaultix extract document.pdf

3. File was removed:

# Check if file exists
vaultix list | grep document

docs.title: "Multiple files match"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix extract doc
Error: multiple files match 'doc': document.pdf, docs.txt

Cause: Fuzzy match is ambiguous.

Solution: Be more specific:

# Use more characters
vaultix extract docum  # Matches only "document.pdf"

# Or use exact name
vaultix extract document.pdf

docs.title: vaultix is very slow
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Commands take many seconds
  • High CPU usage
  • System feels sluggish

Causes & Solutions:

1. Large vault (many files):

# Check number of files
vaultix list | wc -l

# Solution: Split into multiple vaults
mkdir vault1 vault2
# Move some files to vault2

2. Slow storage:

# Check disk speed
dd if=/dev/zero of=test.tmp bs=1M count=100
rm test.tmp

# Solution: Move vault to SSD if possible

3. Limited RAM:

# Check available memory
free -h

# Solution: Close other applications

docs.title: "Out of memory" error
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix add large_file.bin
fatal error: runtime: out of memory

Cause: File too large for available RAM.

Solutions:

1. Close other applications:

# Free up memory
killall chrome

2. Split large file:

# Split into chunks
split -b 100M large_file.bin chunk_

# Add chunks
vaultix add chunk_*

# Later: extract and combine
vaultix extract
cat chunk_* > large_file.bin

3. Increase system RAM:

  • Add more physical RAM
  • Increase swap space (Linux)

docs.title: "Vault corrupted"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix list
Error: vault corrupted: unexpected end of file

Possible causes:

  • Disk errors
  • Incomplete write (power loss, crash)
  • Manual editing of .vaultix files

Solutions:

1. Check disk health:

# Linux
sudo smartctl -a /dev/sda

# macOS
diskutil verifyDisk disk0

# Windows
chkdsk C: /F

2. Restore from backup:

# Copy backup
cp -r /backup/my_vault ~/my_vault_restored
cd ~/my_vault_restored

# Verify
vaultix list

3. Attempt recovery:

# Check vault structure
ls -la .vaultix/
# Should have: salt, meta, objects/

# If salt is missing, vault is unrecoverable
# If meta is corrupted, try older backup

4. Extract what you can:

# Try to list files
vaultix list 2>&1 | tee errors.log

# Try to extract individually
for file in $(vaultix list 2>/dev/null); do
    vaultix extract "$file" || echo "Failed: $file"
done

docs.title: Encrypted files missing
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix list
Error: encrypted file 3f9a2c1d.enc not found

Cause: .vaultix/objects/ files deleted.

Solutions:

1. Restore from backup:

cp -r /backup/vault/.vaultix .

2. If no backup, data is lost:

  • Encrypted files can't be recovered without the .enc files
  • This is why backups are critical!

docs.title: "Operation not permitted" on encrypted filesystems
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ vaultix init
Error: operation not permitted

Cause: Writing to encrypted filesystem (eCryptfs, EncFS).

Solution:

# Move vault to non-encrypted location
mkdir ~/vault
cd ~/vault
vaultix init

# Or adjust filesystem permissions

docs.title: Secure delete doesn't work on ext4
docs.text:
Cause: ext4 file system doesn't guarantee overwrite.

Solution:

  • Use encrypted disk (LUKS)
  • Or use SSD TRIM feature
  • Or use dedicated secure delete tools

docs.title: "Disk full" with plenty of space available
docs.text:
Symptoms:

$ df -h
/dev/disk1  500GB  250GB  250GB  50%  /Users

$ vaultix add large_file
Error: no space left on device

Cause: Spotlight indexing or Time Machine snapshots.

Solution:

# Disable Spotlight indexing for vault
mdutil -i off /path/to/vault

# Or exclude from Time Machine
tmutil addexclusion /path/to/vault

docs.title: Keychain interference
docs.text:
Symptoms: Password prompt appears multiple times.

Solution:

  • vaultix doesn't use Keychain
  • Check for other password manager interference

docs.title: "Access denied" in Program Files
docs.text:
Symptoms:

Error: access denied

Cause: Program Files requires admin rights.

Solution:

# Use user directory
cd %USERPROFILE%\Documents
mkdir vault
cd vault
vaultix init

docs.title: Antivirus quarantines vaultix
docs.text:
Symptoms: Vaultix binary deleted or blocked.

Solution:

  • Add vaultix to antivirus exclusions
  • Download from official GitHub releases only

docs.title: Hidden files not visible
docs.text:
Symptoms: Can't see .vaultix directory in Explorer.

Solution:

# Show hidden files
attrib -h .vaultix

# Or enable "Show hidden files" in Explorer

docs.title: "Someone accessed my vault!"
docs.text:
Steps to take:

1. Change password immediately:

# Extract all files
vaultix extract

# Remove old vault
rm -rf .vaultix

# Reinitialize with new password
vaultix init

2. Check for malware:

# Run antivirus scan
# Check for keyloggers
# Review running processes

3. Review file access logs:

# Linux
sudo journalctl -xe | grep vaultix

# Check file access times
stat .vaultix/meta

4. Move vault to secure location:

  • Encrypted disk
  • Offline storage
  • Air-gapped computer (if very sensitive)

docs.title: Password compromised
docs.text:
What to do:

1. Assume all encrypted data is compromised

2. Change password:

vaultix extract        # Get all files
rm -rf .vaultix        # Delete vault
vaultix init           # New vault with new password

3. Rotate sensitive data:

  • Change API keys
  • Change other passwords stored in vault
  • Update security questions

docs.title: Enable debug output
docs.text:
# Set debug environment variable (if implemented)
export VAULTIX_DEBUG=1
vaultix list

# Or use Go's debugging
go run -race main.go list

docs.title: Check vault structure manually
docs.text:
# Verify .vaultix structure
tree .vaultix
# Should see:
# .vaultix/
# ├── salt
# ├── meta
# ├── config
# └── objects/
#     ├── *.enc files

# Check file sizes
du -sh .vaultix/objects/*

# Verify salt exists and is 32 bytes
ls -l .vaultix/salt
# Should be exactly 32 bytes

docs.title: Test with minimal vault
docs.text:
# Create test vault with one small file
mkdir /tmp/test_vault
cd /tmp/test_vault
echo "test" > test.txt
vaultix init

# If this works, original vault may be corrupted

docs.title: Recover from git
docs.text:
# If vault is in git repo
git log -- .vaultix/
git checkout HEAD~5 -- .vaultix/  # Go back 5 commits
vaultix list  # Try password

docs.title: Before asking for help, collect:
docs.text:
1. Vaultix version:
vaultix --version
  1. Operating system:
uname -a  # Linux/macOS
systeminfo | findstr /B /C:"OS"  # Windows
  1. Error message:
vaultix list 2>&1 | tee error.log
  1. Vault structure (NO passwords!):
tree .vaultix
ls -lah .vaultix/
  1. Steps to reproduce:
  2. What command did you run?
  3. What did you expect?
  4. What actually happened?

docs.title: Where to ask:
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues: https://github.com/Zayan-Mohamed/vaultix/issues
  • GitHub Discussions: https://github.com/Zayan-Mohamed/vaultix/discussions

docs.title: What NOT to share:
docs.text:
• ❌ Passwords
  • ❌ Encrypted file contents
  • ❌ Personal file names
  • ❌ Salt or encryption keys

docs.title: Lost password
docs.text:
Bad news: No recovery possible.

Vaultix uses strong encryption with no backdoor or password reset.

Prevention:

  • Use password manager
  • Write down password and store securely
  • Test password immediately after creating vault

docs.title: Corrupted vault, no backup
docs.text:
Options:

1. Try partial recovery:

# List what can be recovered
vaultix list 2>&1 | grep -v Error

# Extract files one by one
for file in file1.txt file2.pdf; do
    vaultix extract "$file" || continue
done

2. Forensic recovery:

  • Use testdisk or photorec to recover deleted .enc files
  • Professional data recovery service (expensive)

3. Accept data loss:

  • If vault is unrecoverable, data is lost
  • Emphasizes importance of backups

docs.title: Accidentally cleared vault
docs.text:
If you ran vaultix clear:

Immediate actions:

  1. Don't write to disk (increases recovery chance)
  2. Use file recovery tools:
# Linux
sudo extundelete /dev/sda1 --restore-directory .vaultix/objects

# macOS
diskutil list
# Use Time Machine or third-party recovery

# Windows
# Use Recuva or similar tools

Future prevention:

  • Always backup before destructive operations
  • Use confirmation prompts
  • Test on copies, not originals

docs.title: Still Stuck?
docs.text:
If nothing here helps:

  1. Search existing issues: https://github.com/Zayan-Mohamed/vaultix/issues
  2. Ask in discussions: https://github.com/Zayan-Mohamed/vaultix/discussions
  3. Open new issue: Provide all information listed in "Getting Help"

For security vulnerabilities: Email maintainers directly (see SECURITY.md), don't open public issue.

Remember: Backups are your best troubleshooting tool! 💾

docs.title: Usage Guide
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to using Vaultix effectively.

docs.title: What is a Vault?
docs.text:
A vault is a directory containing:

  • A hidden .vaultix/ folder with encrypted data
  • Your encrypted files stored securely

docs.title: How Files Are Stored
docs.text:
my_vault/
└── .vaultix/
    ├── salt          # Random data for key derivation
    ├── meta          # Encrypted filenames and metadata
    └── objects/
        ├── a1b2c3d4.enc  # Your encrypted files
        └── e5f6g7h8.enc  # (with randomized names)

docs.title: Creating a New Vault
docs.text:
Scenario: You have a directory with sensitive files you want to encrypt.

cd ~/Documents/taxes_2024
ls
# tax_return.pdf  receipts.xlsx  statements.pdf

vaultix init
# Enter password: ****
# Confirm password: ****
# ✓ Vault initialized
# ✓ All files encrypted
# ✓ Original files deleted

ls
# .vaultix/  (only this remains)

What happened:

  1. Vaultix scanned for all regular files
  2. Created .vaultix/ structure
  3. Encrypted each file with your password
  4. Securely deleted the originals

docs.title: List Files
docs.text:
vaultix list

# Output:
# Files in vault (3):
#   tax_return.pdf (245 KB, modified: 2024-03-15)
#   receipts.xlsx (128 KB, modified: 2024-03-10)
#   statements.pdf (512 KB, modified: 2024-03-01)

docs.title: Extract a File
docs.text:
# Extract specific file
vaultix extract tax_return.pdf

# Now you can view it
cat tax_return.pdf

Important: The file is still in the vault! extract is non-destructive.

docs.title: Add New Files
docs.text:
# Create a new sensitive file
echo "Bank account: 123456" > account.txt

# Add to vault
vaultix add account.txt

# Original is automatically deleted after encryption
ls account.txt
# ls: cannot access 'account.txt': No such file or directory

docs.title: Remove Files from Vault
docs.text:
Two options:

Option 1: Drop (extract + remove)

vaultix drop old_tax_return.pdf
# ✓ Dropped: old_tax_return.pdf
# File is now decrypted AND removed from vault

Option 2: Remove (delete without extracting)

vaultix remove junk_file.pdf
# File removed from vault (no extraction)

docs.title: Fuzzy File Matching
docs.text:
You don't need to type exact filenames:

# Vault contains: "2024_tax_return_final_v2.pdf"

vaultix extract 2024        # ✓ Matches
vaultix extract tax         # ✓ Matches
vaultix extract TAX         # ✓ Case-insensitive
vaultix extract final       # ✓ Matches
vaultix extract return.pdf  # ✓ Matches

How it works:

  1. Exact match tried first
  2. Case-insensitive exact match
  3. Partial match (contains)

docs.title: Extract Everything
docs.text:
# Extract all files to current directory
vaultix extract

# Extract to specific directory
vaultix extract . /tmp/decrypted/

docs.title: Drop Everything
docs.text:
# Extract all files and clear vault
vaultix drop

# ⚠️  This empties the vault after extracting all files

docs.title: Clear Vault (No Extraction)
docs.text:
vaultix clear
# ⚠️  This will DELETE all files from the vault WITHOUT extracting them.
# Continue? (yes/no): yes
# ✓ Vault cleared

docs.title: Working with Multiple Vaults
docs.text:
You can manage multiple vaults:

# Vault 1: Personal documents
cd ~/personal
vaultix list

# Vault 2: Work files
cd ~/work
vaultix list

# Vault 3: Old archives
vaultix list ~/archives

Each vault has its own:

  • Encryption password
  • Salt
  • Encrypted files

docs.title: Default Behavior (Current Directory)
docs.text:
cd my_vault
vaultix init      # Creates .vaultix in current dir
vaultix list      # Lists current vault
vaultix add file  # Adds to current vault

docs.title: Explicit Paths
docs.text:
# Work from anywhere
vaultix list ~/my_vault
vaultix extract secret ~/my_vault
vaultix add newfile.txt ~/my_vault

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:
# Morning: Extract files you need
cd ~/work_vault
vaultix extract project_plan
vaultix extract api_keys

# ... do your work ...

# Evening: Add new/modified files
vaultix add updated_plan.pdf
vaultix add new_credentials.txt

# Clean up extracted files
rm project_plan.pdf api_keys.json

docs.title: Secure File Transfer
docs.text:
# Sender
cd ~/sensitive_docs
vaultix init
# Creates encrypted vault

# Transfer the entire directory
scp -r ~/sensitive_docs user@server:/tmp/

# Receiver
cd /tmp/sensitive_docs
vaultix extract
# Enter password (communicated securely!)

docs.title: Archiving Old Files
docs.text:
# Create archive vault
mkdir ~/archive_2023
cd ~/archive_2023

# Copy old files
cp ~/Documents/old_project/* .

# Encrypt everything
vaultix init

# Move to backup location
mv ~/archive_2023 /mnt/backup/

docs.title: Rotating Passwords
docs.text:
Currently, Vaultix doesn't support password changes. To rotate:

# Extract everything
vaultix extract

# Delete vault
rm -rf .vaultix

# Re-initialize with new password
vaultix init
# (Creates new vault with new password)

docs.title: Quick Reference Card
docs.text:
Save this to ~/.vaultix_commands:

# Vaultix Quick Reference
init     - Encrypt directory
list     - Show files
extract  - Get file (keeps in vault)
drop     - Get file (removes from vault)
add      - Encrypt new file
remove   - Delete from vault
clear    - Delete all from vault

docs.title: Bash Aliases
docs.text:
Add to ~/.bashrc:

alias vi='vaultix init'
alias vl='vaultix list'
alias ve='vaultix extract'
alias vd='vaultix drop'
alias va='vaultix add'

docs.title: Password Manager Integration
docs.text:
Use pass (Unix password manager):

# Store vault password
pass insert vaultix/my_vault

# Use it
vaultix list
# Password: $(pass vaultix/my_vault)

docs.title: Backup Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# backup-vault.sh

VAULT_DIR="$HOME/my_vault"
BACKUP_DIR="/mnt/backup/vaults"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d)

# Copy entire vault (encrypted)
cp -r "$VAULT_DIR" "$BACKUP_DIR/my_vault_$DATE"

echo "✓ Vault backed up to $BACKUP_DIR/my_vault_$DATE"

docs.title: Verification Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# verify-vault.sh

cd ~/my_vault

echo "Files in vault:"
vaultix list

echo ""
echo "Vault structure:"
ls -lR .vaultix/

docs.title: "Vault not found"
docs.text:
# Check if .vaultix exists
ls -la .vaultix

# If not, you're in wrong directory
pwd

docs.title: "Failed to decrypt"
docs.text:
• Wrong password
  • Corrupted vault
  • Vault from different vaultix version

docs.title: "File not found"
docs.text:
• Check spelling: vaultix list
  • Use fuzzy matching: vaultix extract part_of_name

docs.title: "Permission denied"
docs.text:
# Fix .vaultix permissions
chmod 700 .vaultix
chmod 600 .vaultix/*

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always backup vaults before experimenting
  2. Test your password immediately after creating a vault
  3. Use strong passwords (16+ characters)
  4. Clean up extracted files when done
  5. Keep vaults on encrypted drives when possible
  6. Don't mix vault and work directories (extract to separate folder)
